importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating the current timeline of the federal government shutdown and the imminent risk of food stamp disbursement failure in November.
The start date of the federal government shutdown, which triggered the funding crisis for food stamp and WIC programs, setting the context for the current emergency.
The date when Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins made public statements about the depletion of food stamp funds, reinforcing urgency in the situation.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The two-week period before November payments are due, during which the USDA warns that SNAP benefits will run out unless emergency or supplemental funding is provided.

keyTakeAways: Roughly 42 million Americans are at risk of losing food stamp benefits in November due to the federal government shutdown.
The USDA has confirmed that it lacks sufficient funds to pay full SNAP benefits in November without intervention or contingency funding.
The Trump administration has not committed to providing additional funds to sustain SNAP, unlike its actions for other programs such as WIC, which used tariff revenue to stay operational.
About one in eight Americans relies on food stamps, with an average monthly benefit of $188 per person.
The SNAP program has a $6 billion contingency fund, but it is insufficient to cover the projected $8 billion in November benefits.
17 states have halted new food stamp applications due to the inability to issue partial October and November payments simultaneously.
The crisis is part of a broader political standoff between Republicans and Democrats over a federal spending deal that includes expiring Obamacare subsidies.
Democrats blame Republicans for refusing to negotiate a spending package that includes extended subsidies, while Republicans blame Democrats for prioritizing political agendas over food security.
New York Governor Kathy Hochul criticized the administration for deliberately halting benefits, calling it an attack on vulnerable families.
The food stamp program is the second nutrition assistance program at risk; WIC was previously affected, but was temporarily stabilized with $300 million in tariff revenue.
The situation is not unprecedented â€” in 2018, a similar shutdown led to a temporary funding workaround that avoided full collapse.
Advocacy groups stress that Thanksgiving is approaching, making the timing of food assistance especially critical.
Experts urge the administration to act urgently to protect vulnerable households from food insecurity.

namedEntities.name: Brooke Rollins
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the official who publicly announced the depletion of SNAP funding and blamed Democrats for political interference in food security.

namedEntities.name: Kathy Hochul
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She criticized the Trump administration for halting food stamp benefits, calling it a deliberate and harmful action against vulnerable families.

namedEntities.name: Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the central program at risk of interruption during the shutdown, affecting millions of low-income Americans.

namedEntities.name: WIC (Women, Infants, and Children)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is another nutrition program at risk, though temporarily stabilized by a $300 million tariff revenue infusion.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is responsible for the decision to halt SNAP payments and to shift tariff revenue to WIC, drawing criticism for prioritizing political agendas over food security.

namedEntities.name: Democrats
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are accused of pushing political agendas, such as extending Obamacare subsidies, which Republicans argue obstructs spending negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Republicans
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are blamed by Democrats for refusing to negotiate a spending deal, leading to the shutdown and subsequent funding crises.

namedEntities.name: Obamacare premium subsidies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Their extension is a point of contention in the spending negotiations that led to the shutdown and affected the broader political discourse.

namedEntities.name: Tariff revenue
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It was redirected to keep WIC running, but not sufficient to fund SNAP benefits for November.

namedEntities.name: Federal government shutdown
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It directly caused the funding lapse that threatens food stamp and WIC programs.

namedEntities.name: Food Research & Action Center
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It emphasizes the critical role of food stamps in helping low-income families, especially around Thanksgiving.

namedEntities.name: Center on Budget and Policy Priorities
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It calls for urgent action to prevent households from being left without food assistance during the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Thanksgiving
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The approaching holiday makes food security especially urgent, as families prepare for holiday meals.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Amid a federal government shutdown that began on October 1, 2025, the U.S. Department of Agriculture warns that the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), commonly known as food stamps, will run out of funds by early November. Approximately 42 million Americans are at risk of losing critical food assistance, with 17 states halting new applications due to payment system limitations. Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins attributes the crisis to political disagreements, blaming Democrats for prioritizing their agenda over food security. The Trump administration has not committed to funding SNAP, unlike its intervention in WIC, which used $300 million in tariff revenue to stay afloat. Despite a $6 billion contingency fund, the $8 billion needed for November benefits cannot be covered. Democrats counter that Republicans are unwilling to negotiate a spending deal that includes extended Obamacare subsidies. Advocacy groups stress the urgency, especially with Thanksgiving approaching, and call for immediate action to protect vulnerable families from food insecurity.
title: Millions of Americans at Risk of Losing Food Stamps Next Month Amid Shutdown
